subject: Make UpdateDeployment depend on NetworkDeployment
commit_message:
Make UpdateDeployment depend on NetworkDeployment

Prior to https://review.openstack.org/#/c/271450/ os-net-config was
applied via os-refresh-config directly, which meant that even though
UpdateDeployment and NetworkDeployment can be created concurrently,
we'd always do the os-net-config step first.

However now that we apply both steps via scripts (which are both handled
via the same heat-config hook) we should add an explicit dependency to
ensure the network is always fully configured before attempting to run
any update.  This should avoid the risk of e.g running an update on
initial deployment before the network connectivity to access yum repos
is in place.

subject: Setsid to fix "old" screen_it--screen_stop chain
commit_message:
Setsid to fix "old" screen_it--screen_stop chain

functions-common:screen_it utilizes _old_run_process in case of a
non-screen environment such as grenade testing.  However this call-chain
fails to store correct PID/PGID in order for a service to be stopped by
screen_stop later on.  The issue boils down to following (simplified) code:

    function _old_run_process() {
        local command=$2
        exec /bin/bash -c "$command"
    }

    _old_run_process service-name "cd workdir && \
                                   ./service --config service.conf" &
    echo $! > state/service.pid

The issue is two-fold. The pid of the sub-shell is being saved instead of
the service "$command" pid.  The screen_stop chain uses pkill -g (-F)
state/service.pid to terminate the whole service process group.

Since pid of the subshell is saved instead of the pgid of the service,
pkill -g fails with exit code 1 (target not found).  If a correct pgid was
saved instead (echo `ps -opgid= $!` > state/service.pid), due to pgid
implicit inheritance the pkill command would have killed the whole grenade
process group.

Suggested change utilizes setsid to generate new pgid (and sid) of the
service instead:

    function _old_run_process() {
        local command=$2
        exec setsid /bin/bash -c "$command"
    }

    _old_run_process service-name "cd workdir && \
                                   ./service --config service.conf" &
    echo $! > state/service.pid

Because exec is used here, setsid isn't forked as a separate process but
rather replaces subshell process instance while maintaining all
redirection.  Setsid uses its pid to create new pgid and sid of a
"$command" that ist's going to exec, again, without forking.  Since that
pid is stored in the parent shell ($!), it can be used as the pgid (and
sid) of the service process eventually forked by bash in the "$command".
This pgid being different from parent shell's, it is safe to pkill -g that
pgid to stop the service only (the forked service has ppid==1,
pgid==sid==$!, pid==<new pid>). That effectively turns the service into a
demon process.

Correctness of this change can be checked by executing pstree -pg instead
of "$command" to show the shell relationship as well as pid and pgid of
each process involved.

Change-Id: I265538ef9e9925ee64477ae127fd050e6133d578
Closes-Bug: 1595225

subject: Allow sharded container to be deleted (when empty)
commit_message:
Allow sharded container to be deleted (when empty)

This is a *simple* delete strategy - if the root container thinks it is
empty then it is OK to delete it.

The root will not consider itself empty until (a) all objects have
been deleted and (b) all shards have updated their usage (i.e. the
sharders have passed over them), so there may be some delay between
object deletes and the root being deletable. That is analogous to a
normal container being undeletable because some delete updates dropped
into an async pending queue.

We can do better, but this allows us to delete at some point.

subject: Add root_execution_id to sub-workflow executions
commit_message:
Add root_execution_id to sub-workflow executions

For sub-workflow executions this will be the ID of the initial workflow
execution. For example, given the following workflows.

workflows:
  wf1:
    tasks:
      task1:
        workflow: wf2

  wf2:
    tasks:
      task1:
        workflow: wf3

  wf3:
    tasks:
      task1:
        action: std.noop

When we start wf1, it calls wf2 which calls wf3. Currently, it is hard to
retrieve the full execution, including sub-workflow executions. This patch adds
the root_execution_id to the sub-workflows, so the execution for wf2 and wf3
have a root_execution_id that is the ID of the execution for wf1. The execution
for wf1 is the root execution, so root_execution_id is None. This basically
gives us a flat reference to the graph of workflow executions.

This change is useful as we can then expose it via the API and it makes
it easier and more efficient to find a full execution, including it's
sub-workflow executions.

Implements: blueprint mistral-root-execution-id
Change-Id: I24638812caa2e48e3c071925db5e552b21e15d47
(cherry picked from commit 053308e7c397de0e3c12514c8ef5f6c22f9b3f3d)

ipmitool: reboot: Don't power off node if already off

Commit ee5d4942a1c33736ffe05ec01619142be400c2f4 changed the existing
behavior so that if an ipmitool command fails when attempting to set
the power state it causes a failure.  The problem with that approach

subject: Allow logging of unhashable exceptions in Python 3
commit_message:
Allow logging of unhashable exceptions in Python 3

A bug in the Python 3 standard library,
https://bugs.python.org/issue28603 means that calling the traceback
module with an exception chain that includes an unhashable exception
results in a TypeError being raised. (In Python 3, any classes that
define __eq__() without also explicitly defining - not inheriting -
__hash__() will be unhashable.) The TypeError itself is also part of
such a chain, since its __context__ will be the unhashable exception. If
we don't catch it then the thread will simply exit mysteriously, and no
amount of logging will be able to reveal to the user what happened.

Change-Id: I6768574f38b075c15e829df5593a45c6be66b1bc

subject: Scoped policies for server groups
commit_message:
Scoped policies for server groups

Server groups are currently used to ensure that instances in the
groups are either grouped together on the same host (affinity) or
spread across different hosts (anti-affinity).  This
affinity/anti-affinity concept could be broadly useful for a number of
use cases, but many of these use cases would require (anti-)affinity
with a scope broader than a single host.  This spec adds a general and
flexible scoping mechanism to server group policies which enables
these use cases.  Under this mechanism, "host" is just one of
(potentially) many available scopes; by making host the default scope
if none is specified, this mechanism is fully backward-compatible with
the existing server group policies.  Arbitrary additional scopes can
be defined by the deployer.

Sometimes when a request to build or resize a VM is attempted, the build
can fail for a variety of different reasons. At recent PTG and Forum
events we discussed a request from operators to still be able to retry
failed builds. With the cells V2 design, though, the communication from
